sdo:itemDesc.dc:title: Diary entry by Schenker November 1, 1934
sdo:itemDesc.dc:description: A summary of the contents of the record (currently unused)
sdo:itemDesc.dc:subject: A list of subjects (currently unused)

tei:div.tei:opener: 1. November 1934 Wendet sich ins Nasse bei 8°!

tei:ab.tei:seg: Ein neues Mädchen!
Dr. Wurmfeld: die Medikamente weiter!
An Kammerer (K.): Mittwoch, den 7. XI.!
An Herrn Guttmann (Visitenk.): Beileid.
Bleiben bei Regen daheim.

tei:div.tei:opener: November 1, 1934, becoming wet at a temperature of 8°!

tei:ab.tei:seg: A new maid!
Dr. Wurmfeld: continue to take the medications!
To Kammerer (postcard): Wednesday, November 7!
To Mr. Guttmann (visiting-card): condolences.
Because of the rain, we stay home.

sdo:itemDesc.dc:title: Diary entry by Schenker November 2, 1934
sdo:itemDesc.dc:description: A summary of the contents of the record (currently unused)
sdo:itemDesc.dc:subject: A list of subjects (currently unused)

tei:ab.tei:seg: Von Callwey S. 51!!
Die Kultusgemeinde fordert einen „freiwilligen Zuschlag“!

Salzer empfiehlt sich englisch? That is, he is taking a leave of absence without permission or explanation. The English idiom is "to take French leave"; the equivalent French idiom – which Schenker is using, in German translation – is "filer à l’anglaise."
Jetty von ½5–5h: klagt über Alterserscheinungen, bereut die frühere turbulente Art.

Requiem aus dem Dom According to the radio listings in the Neue freie Presse, Mozart’s Requiem, performed in memory of Engelbert Dollfuß and the victims of the February Uprising (1934), was broadcast from the Cathedral of St. Stephen. The cathedral’s music director, Ferdinand Habel, conducted the choral society Dreizehnlinden and the Vienna Symphony Orchestra; the soloists were Erika Rokyta (soprano), Emilie Rutschka (alto), Hermann Gallos (tenor), and Josef Manowarda (bass). – Patiençe im Musikzimmer.
From Callwey, 51 shillings!!
The Jewish Religious Community requests a "voluntary surcharge"!
Salzer is taking French leave?
Jetty from 4:30 to 5 o’clock: she complains about the signs of ageing, regrets her earlier, turbulent way of life.
Requiem from St. Stephen’s Cathedral – Solitaire played in the music room.

sdo:itemDesc.dc:title: Diary entry by Schenker November 3, 1934
sdo:itemDesc.dc:description: A summary of the contents of the record (currently unused)
sdo:itemDesc.dc:subject: A list of subjects (currently unused)

tei:ab.tei:seg: Wilfort von 11–½12h: fürchtet mich verletzt zu haben; über ein Mißverständnis Salzer – Tischler Possibly Hans Tischler (1915–2010). A Viennese by birth, he received a Ph.D. from the University of Vienna in 1937 on Mahler, and from Yale University in 1942 on Notre Dame polyphony; in the USA, he had a long and distinguished career as a musicologist, primarily as a medieval music scholar. – Steuermann: S. 15–25.
Wolf zur 1. Stunde.
Nach der Jause Wege.
Von Weigl (K.): wird warten, liest die „IX.“, ladet zu einem Quartettabend mit Busch ein.
Von Arnold (Br.): retournirt Victors Brief u. aus der Familiengeschichte.
Willfort from 11 o’clock to 11:30: he is afraid of having injured me; concerning a misunderstanding about Salzer – Tischler – Steuermann: 15–25 shillings.
Wolf for his first lesson.
After teatime, errands.
From Weigl (postcard): he will wait, is reading the Ninth Symphony, invites us to a quartet evening with Busch.
From Arnold (letter): returns Victor’s letter, and recounts from the family history.

sdo:itemDesc.dc:title: Diary entry by Schenker November 4, 1934
sdo:itemDesc.dc:description: A summary of the contents of the record (currently unused)
sdo:itemDesc.dc:subject: A list of subjects (currently unused)

tei:ab.tei:seg: Violin.
Im Café Aspang bis 7h.
Korrekturen für Der freie Satz.
Violin.
At the Café Aspang until 7 o’clock.
Proof corrections to Free Composition.

sdo:itemDesc.dc:title: Diary entry by Schenker November 5, 1934
sdo:itemDesc.dc:description: A summary of the contents of the record (currently unused)
sdo:itemDesc.dc:subject: A list of subjects (currently unused)

tei:ab.tei:seg: Das Fläschchen zur Analyse.
An Frl. Kahn (K.): den 1. u. 3. Montag von 5–6h.
Dr. Ettl bei Buchner kennen gelernt: möchte etwas von meinem System wissen – eine halbe Stunde!?!
Befund: 0.9 – auch etwas Eiweiß!
Nach der Jause Wege.
Abends 9h von Salzer (Br. expreßOC 44/2): möchte mich Mittwoch sprechen.
An Wolf (K. expreß): Mittwoch ¾11h!
The sample taken for analysis.
To Miss Kahn (postcard): the first and third Mondays of the month, from 5 to 6 o’clock.
Dr. Ettl met at Buchner’s: he would like to learn something about my system – half an hour!?!
Result: 0.9% sugar – also some protein!
After teatime, errands.
At 9 o’clock in the evening, from Salzer (express letterOC 44/2): he would like to speak with me on Wednesday.
To Wolf (express postcard): Wednesday at 10:45!

sdo:itemDesc.dc:title: Diary entry by Schenker November 6, 1934
sdo:itemDesc.dc:description: A summary of the contents of the record (currently unused)
sdo:itemDesc.dc:subject: A list of subjects (currently unused)

tei:ab.tei:seg: Beim Frühstück heftiger Schwindelanfall! Dr. Wurmfeld kommt bald u. beruhigt mich. Nachts heftige Schmerzen gehabt!
At breakfast, a severe fainting spell! Dr. Wurmfeld comes quickly and calms me. Severe pains at night!
Hoboken brings two issues of the Zeitschrift für Musikwissenschaft, Nageli; concerning Zuckmayr.

sdo:itemDesc.dc:title: Diary entry by Schenker November 7, 1934
sdo:itemDesc.dc:description: A summary of the contents of the record (currently unused)
sdo:itemDesc.dc:subject: A list of subjects (currently unused)

tei:ab.tei:seg: es wird nicht geheizt (aber dumm war es!!).
Korrekturen für Der freie Satz.
Wolf um ½11h, Salzer zur ersten Stunde.
Nach der Jause zur Apotheke, wieder unbehaglich.
Kammerer.
Rf. Willy u. Roseneck: Schubert, Schumann, Wolf – eine feierlich schöne Leistung Beider!
we do not heat the apartment (but that was stupid!!).
Proof corrections to Free Composition.
Wolf at 10:30, Salzer for his first lesson.
After teatime, to the pharmacy, again uncomfortably.
Kammerer.
Radio, Willy and Roseneck: Schubert, Schumann, Wolf – a ceremoniously fine accomplishment by both!

sdo:itemDesc.dc:title: Diary entry by Schenker November 8, 1934
sdo:itemDesc.dc:description: A summary of the contents of the record (currently unused)
sdo:itemDesc.dc:subject: A list of subjects (currently unused)

tei:ab.tei:seg: Teleph. an Hirsch: darf ich die 1. Korrektur behalten für Der freie Satz? – ja!
Von Kromer Parte – an ihm Vis. K.: Beileid!
By telephone to Hirsch: may I keep the first set of proof corrections to Free Composition? – Yes!
From Kromer, obituary – to him, visiting-card: condolences!

sdo:itemDesc.dc:title: Diary entry by Schenker November 9, 1934
sdo:itemDesc.dc:description: A summary of the contents of the record (currently unused)
sdo:itemDesc.dc:subject: A list of subjects (currently unused)

tei:ab.tei:seg: An Jonas (Br.): erwäge die Chançen einer Klage.
Von Oppel (Br.): er ist herzleidend! Allerlei aus Schule u. Kreis.
v. H. bringt Konzert- u. Theatertratsch – um 6h sagt er: „Das nächste Mal wollen wir gleich anfangen.“ Er ladet sich zur Jause!
Um 8h abends erkundigt sich Halberstam, Lie-Liechen ladet ihn ein!
To Jonas (letter): I assess the prospects of legal action.
From Oppel (letter): he is brokenhearted! Various things from his school and circle.
Hoboken brings gossip from the concert hall and theater; at 6 o’clock he says: "The next time we’ll begin immediately." He invites himself to stay for a snack!
At 8 o’clock, Halberstam inquires about us; Lie-Liechen invites him over!

sdo:itemDesc.dc:title: Diary entry by Schenker November 10, 1934
sdo:itemDesc.dc:description: A summary of the contents of the record (currently unused)
sdo:itemDesc.dc:subject: A list of subjects (currently unused)

tei:ab.tei:seg: Um 11h Dr. Wurmfeld.
Korrekturen zu Der freie Satz.
Wir bleiben zuhause.
Dr. Wurmfeld at 11 o’clock.
Proof corrections to Free Composition.
We stay at home.

sdo:itemDesc.dc:title: Diary entry by Schenker November 11, 1934
sdo:itemDesc.dc:description: A summary of the contents of the record (currently unused)
sdo:itemDesc.dc:subject: A list of subjects (currently unused)

tei:ab.tei:seg: Deutsch beim Telephon: wann v. Hoboken reist?
Die Jause bei Volkert.
Vorlesung Zuckmayer.
Deutsch on the telephone: when is Hoboken going on his travels?
Afternoon snack at Volkert.
On the radio: lecture by Zuckmayer.

sdo:itemDesc.dc:title: Diary entry by Schenker November 12, 1934
sdo:itemDesc.dc:description: A summary of the contents of the record (currently unused)
sdo:itemDesc.dc:subject: A list of subjects (currently unused)

tei:ab.tei:seg: Korrekturen zu Der freie Satz.

Mengelberg mit den Budapester Philharmoniker einiges besonders u. schön! According to the listings in Radio Wien, the concert, which included a "sinfonietta" by Johann Christian Bach, Beethoven’s Sixth Symphony and Tchaikovsky’s Fifth, was broadcast from Budapest.
Proof corrections to Free Composition.
Mengelberg with the Budapest Philharmonic: some things special, and beautiful!

sdo:itemDesc.dc:title: Diary entry by Schenker November 13, 1934
sdo:itemDesc.dc:description: A summary of the contents of the record (currently unused)
sdo:itemDesc.dc:subject: A list of subjects (currently unused)

tei:ab.tei:seg: An Dr. Fuchs (Br. Lie-Liechen): bitten um einen Erlagschein u. senden ein Autogramm (Klemperer).
v. Hoboken bleibt 1½ Stunde, bin nachher sehr müde! v. H. beschließt die Herausgabe von Der freie Satz bei der U.-E., unter Kontrolle der Tantiemen durch Rochlitzer.
Lie-Liechen bittet den Arzt.
To Dr. Fuchs (letter from Lie-Liechen): we request a payment slip, and send an autograph (of Klemperer).
Hoboken stays for an hour and a half; afterwards I am very tired! Hoboken resolves on publication of Free Composition by UE on condition that Rochlitzer has control of the royalties.
Lie-Liechen requests a visit from the doctor.

sdo:itemDesc.dc:title: Diary entry by Schenker November 14, 1934
sdo:itemDesc.dc:description: A summary of the contents of the record (currently unused)
sdo:itemDesc.dc:subject: A list of subjects (currently unused)

tei:ab.tei:seg: Versuch Wolf u. Salzer an einem Vormittag.
Dr. Wurmfeld überrascht mich (!?!) um 11h (Wolf hat vergessen, daß er um ½11h kommen sollte) – verschreibt Brom.
Nach der Jause mit Lie-Liechen Wege.
Attempt to schedule Wolf and Salzer for the same morning.
Dr. Wurmfeld surprises me (!?!) at 11 o’clock (Wolf forgot that he was supposed to come at 10:30) – he proscribes bromide.
After teatime, errands with Lie-Liechen.

sdo:itemDesc.dc:title: Diary entry by Schenker November 15, 1934
sdo:itemDesc.dc:description: A summary of the contents of the record (currently unused)
sdo:itemDesc.dc:subject: A list of subjects (currently unused)

tei:ab.tei:seg: Rothberger trotz Feiertag.
Jause bei Meinl: ganz günstig.
Ein süßes Schäferstündchen bei Korrekturen des Vorworts zu Der freie Satz; Lie-Liechen in Blüte u. Duft der Aufgabe u. Ausführung: Dank!
Rothberger, in spite of it being a holiday.
Afternoon snack at Meinl: very reasonable.
An intimate hour on the correction of the Foreword to Free Composition; Lie-Liechen fully geared up for the assignment and its realization: thank you!

sdo:itemDesc.dc:title: Diary entry by Schenker November 16, 1934
sdo:itemDesc.dc:description: A summary of the contents of the record (currently unused)
sdo:itemDesc.dc:subject: A list of subjects (currently unused)

tei:ab.tei:seg: Fahnen von der U.-E..
Lie-Liechen bittet Frau Rothberger für Samstag.
Halberstam erkundigt sich telephonisch, obgleich selbst an Grippe erkrankt, nach meinem Befinden.

Lie-Liechen an der Rein-
schrift des Vorworts zu Der freie Satz.
Galley proofs from UE.
Lie-Liechen invites Mrs. Rothberger for Saturday.
Halberstam asks about my health via telephone, even though he is himself ill with the flu.

Lie-Liechen at work on the fair
copy of the Foreword to Free Composition.

sdo:itemDesc.dc:title: Diary entry by Schenker November 17, 1934
sdo:itemDesc.dc:description: A summary of the contents of the record (currently unused)
sdo:itemDesc.dc:subject: A list of subjects (currently unused)

tei:ab.tei:seg: Von Weigl Einladung zur Uraufführung eines Streichquartetts in Gdur.
Violin von 11–½12h.
Wolf von ½12–1h!!!
Frau Rothberger von ½6–½9h: trostlose, haltlose Frau, sich u. der Familie unnütz, nur einer fFessellosigkeit lebend, sich an Alle u. Alles nach Gelegenheit hängend, ohne eigene Substanz.
From Weigl: invitation to the premiere of his String Quartet in G major.
Violin from 11 to 11:30.
Wolf from 11:30 to 1 o’clock!!!

Mrs. Rothberger from 5:30 to 8:30: disconsolate, disoriented lady, of no use to herself or her family, merely leading a directionless life, hanging upon everyone and everything as the occasion arises, without any substance of her own.

sdo:itemDesc.dc:title: Diary entry by Schenker November 18, 1934
sdo:itemDesc.dc:description: A summary of the contents of the record (currently unused)
sdo:itemDesc.dc:subject: A list of subjects (currently unused)

tei:ab.tei:seg: Im Erker an Korrekturen zu Der freie Satz.
An die U.-E. (Br. an Roth): Fahne 35 wegen der Figurenzahlen.
Jause bei Meinl mit Herrn u. Frau v. Hoboken, dann das neue Sacher-Local betrachtet, vielleicht doch besser als Meinl.
Mit Lie-Liechen Fahnen durchgegangen, Dank, gute Nacht!
In the alcove, at work on the proof corrections to Free Composition.
To UE (letter to Roth): galley-proof 35, on account of the numbers for the music examples.
Afternoon snack at Meinl with Mr. and Mrs. Hoboken, then the new Sacher premises examined, perhaps actually better than Meinl.
With Lie-Liechen, the galley proofs examined: thank you, good night!

sdo:itemDesc.dc:title: Diary entry by Schenker November 19, 1934
sdo:itemDesc.dc:description: A summary of the contents of the record (currently unused)
sdo:itemDesc.dc:subject: A list of subjects (currently unused)

tei:ab.tei:seg: An Frieda (Br.): Gratulation.

Nach Tisch: Mercur wegen der Trefferanleihe Trefferanleihe: a lottery bond, offered on a subscription basis by the Austrian Federal Government in October 1933 at a rate of interest of 4%; it offered additional profit incentives by taking part in a lottery, and by a cover against loss in value. (AEIOU-Österreich Lexikon online) u. der S. 2.05 an Hesse.
Im Auto zur Post u. zu Prof. Fuchs: „sehr gut“ – im Auto heim.

Ludwig Bednař (wegen eines Geldgebers!?): erzählt von der Mutter Frauliches, Allzufrauliches (Menschliches, Allzumenschliches ist besser gesagt!!), Stückchen von der Steuerbehörde, die mir zu denken geben!
Fahnen für Der freie Satz bis S. 46.
To Frieda (letter): congratulations.
After lunch: to the Mercur on account of the lottery bond, and the 2.05 shillings for Hesse.
By automobile to the post office and to Prof. Fuchs: "very good" – home by automobile.

Ludwig Bednař (on account of a benefactor!?): he speaks about his mother in womanly, all too womanly terms (it would have been better to say "human, all too human"!!); a small piece from the tax authorities, which gives me something to be concerned with!
Galley proofs for Free Composition up to p. 46.

sdo:itemDesc.dc:title: Diary entry by Schenker November 20, 1934
sdo:itemDesc.dc:description: A summary of the contents of the record (currently unused)
sdo:itemDesc.dc:subject: A list of subjects (currently unused)

tei:ab.tei:seg: Von der U.-E. Fahnen her u. hin.

Von Frau Mader (Br. expressOC 30/77): wegen des Schubert-Lied-Schlusses, der ihr zu ihrem preisgekrönten Text nicht paßt. On September 25, 1934, the Austrian radio corporation (RAVAG), at Deutsch’s suggestion, organized a competition whereby a suitable text for an untexted Schubert song was sought. As the song was also unfinished, it was first completed by Schenker (see Otto Erich Deutsch, Ein Preissauschreiben der RAVAG. Ein Schubert-Lied ohne Worte, Radio Wien, No. 52, September 21, 1934, 10th year, pp. 6, 13, 20). The competition was won by Prisca Maria Mader; her letter to Schenker is preserved as OC 30/77.
An Frau Deutsch (tel.): habe nichts dagegen, ein ) schützt Schubert gegen jedermann, auch gegen mich.
An Frau Mader (Br. mit Beilagen): sie mache, wie sie will u. kann.
Von Dr. Ernst Fuchs Note (10 S.) u. Erlagschein.
From UE, galley proofs hither and thither.
From Mrs. Mader (express letterOC 30/77): concerning my ending for the Schubert song, which does not fit her prize-wining text.
To Mrs. Deutsch (by telephone): I have nothing against it, a footnote protects Schubert against everyone, myself also included.
To Mrs. Mader (letter with enclosures): she may do as best she can, and is willing.
From Dr. Ernst Fuchs note (10 shillings), and payment slip.

sdo:itemDesc.dc:title: Diary entry by Schenker November 21, 1934
sdo:itemDesc.dc:description: A summary of the contents of the record (currently unused)
sdo:itemDesc.dc:subject: A list of subjects (currently unused)

tei:ab.tei:seg: Lie-Liechen ruft Dr. Wurmfeld wegen ihrer Zunge: „Das ist ein Biß“!! Mich findet er gut.
Nach der Jause bis zur Apotheke.
Lie-Liechen ladet Dr. Lanzer zu einer Jause, Samstag ½6h.
An Dr. Halberstam (Br.): Dank für die Erkundigung, Fuchs u. Wurmfeld finden mich „sehr gut“.
An Violin (K.OJ 8/5, [36]): über die günstigen Befunde, Braun überflüssig.

Rf.: Backhaus spielt Mozarts Klavierkonzert Ad: According to the listings in Radio Wien, this was the later of Mozart’s two concertos in A major, K.488. der Gebrauch der Finger müßte ihm untersagt werden; Fingerkastration!
Lie-Liechen telephones Dr. Wurmfeld on account of her tongue: "That is a bite"!! He finds me well.
After teatime, as far as the pharmacy.
Lie-Liechen invites Dr. Lanzer to afternoon snack, Saturday at 5:30.
To Dr. Halberstam (letter): thanks for the inquiry; Fuchs and Wurmfeld find me "very well."
To Violin (postcardOJ 8/5, [36]): on the favorable results; consulting Braun is unnecessary.
Radio: Backhaus plays Mozart’s Piano Concerto in A major: he should be forbidden from using his fingers; finger castration!

sdo:itemDesc.dc:title: Diary entry by Schenker November 22, 1934
sdo:itemDesc.dc:description: A summary of the contents of the record (currently unused)
sdo:itemDesc.dc:subject: A list of subjects (currently unused)

tei:ab.tei:seg: Der Brief an Frau Mader kommt als unbestellbar zurück.
Nach der Jause teilt Lie-Liechen der Frau Deutsch dies mit; sie wird den Brief abholen lassen, da die Adressatin heute ihr Gast sei.
An Oppel einen Brief begonnen; das Herzleiden vielleicht nur Täuschung wie bei mir?
Frl. Elias bringt die IV. Sinfonie von Beethoven aus dem Archiv.
My letter to Mrs. Mader is returned as undeliverable.
After teatime, Lie-Liechen communicates the following to Mrs. Deutsch: she should arrange for the letter to be collected, since the addressee is her guest for the day.
To Oppel, a letter begun; his heartache is perhaps merely a deception, as is the case with me?
Miss Elias brings Beethoven’s Fourth Symphony from the Archive.

sdo:itemDesc.dc:title: Diary entry by Schenker November 23, 1934
sdo:itemDesc.dc:description: A summary of the contents of the record (currently unused)
sdo:itemDesc.dc:subject: A list of subjects (currently unused)

tei:ab.tei:seg: Brief an Oppel geht ab.
An der Handschrift. The autograph score of Beethoven’s Fourth Symphony; see diary entry for November 22.
An Weigl (K.OJ 5/44a, [1]): ich muß dem Abend fernbleiben, mehr mündlich.
v. Hoboken hat an der Handschrift Interesse, ja Freude!
Letter to Oppel sent off.
Study of the manuscript.
To Weigl (postcardOJ 5/44a, [1]): I must be absent from the evening concert; more in person.
Hoboken takes an interest – indeed, joy! – in the manuscript.

sdo:itemDesc.dc:title: Diary entry by Schenker November 24, 1934
sdo:itemDesc.dc:description: A summary of the contents of the record (currently unused)
sdo:itemDesc.dc:subject: A list of subjects (currently unused)

tei:ab.tei:seg: Korrekturen zu Der freie Satz.
Dr. Lanzer zum Thee von 6–½9h! –: Plausch, zum Schluß: die geplante Schenkung macht keine Umstände; – Mozio kam nicht zur Sprache.
Sehr ermüdet, spät zu Bett.
Proof corrections to Free Composition.
Dr. Lanzer for tea from 6 to 8:30! Gossip, at the end: the planned donation causes no difficulties; Mozio did not come up in the conversation.
Thoroughly exhausted, late to bed.

sdo:itemDesc.dc:title: Diary entry by Schenker November 25, 1934
sdo:itemDesc.dc:description: A summary of the contents of the record (currently unused)
sdo:itemDesc.dc:subject: A list of subjects (currently unused)

tei:ab.tei:seg: Bis 12h an den Korrekturen Der freie Satz.
Die Jause bei Sacher, dann ein Stück Kärntnerstraße, windstill, erquickend.

Heitere Sendung. Presumably the radio potpourri "Viennese Melodies," assembled by Lothar Riedinger and broadcast from 8:30 until 9:50. Numerous soloists and ensembles performed under the direction of Josef Holzer (see the listings in Radio Wien and the Neue freie Presse).
Until 12 o’clock, at work on the corrections to Free Composition.
Afternoon snack at the Sacher, then a stretch of the Kärntnerstraße, windless, refreshing.
Cheerful broadcast.

sdo:itemDesc.dc:title: Diary entry by Schenker November 26, 1934
sdo:itemDesc.dc:description: A summary of the contents of the record (currently unused)
sdo:itemDesc.dc:subject: A list of subjects (currently unused)

tei:ab.tei:seg: Wieder ein neues Mädchen!
Ich untersage dem Frl. Kahn ihre „Stimmführung“ an Frl. Goldschmid als von Schenker kommend weiterzugeben!
Zuhause.
Yet another new maid!
I forbid Miss Kahn to send her "voice leading" to Miss Goldschmid as coming from Schenker!
At home.

sdo:itemDesc.dc:title: Diary entry by Schenker November 27, 1934
sdo:itemDesc.dc:description: A summary of the contents of the record (currently unused)
sdo:itemDesc.dc:subject: A list of subjects (currently unused)

tei:ab.tei:seg: Von Deutsch (K.OC A/279): es bleibt bei meiner Fassung des Schubert-Liedes. On September 25, 1934, the Austrian radio corporation (RAVAG), at Deutsch’s suggestion, organized a competition whereby a suitable text for an untexted Schubert song was sought. As the song was also unfinished, it was first completed by Schenker (see Otto Erich Deutsch, Ein Preissauschreiben der RAVAG. Ein Schubert-Lied ohne Worte, Radio Wien, No. 52, September 21, 1934, 10th year, pp. 6, 13, 20). The competition was won by Prisca Maria Mader who wrote to Schenker on November 18 to say that she was not satisfied with his completion (OC 30/77; see diary entry for November 20).
An Deutsch (K.): werde zuhören.

Violin von ¾11–¾12h: erzählt die Geschichte seiner Bewerbung um die Ravag u. liest den Brief von Ast u. die Ablehnung durch Kabasta vor. Ueber ein Gespräch des mit Dr. Löwenherz, des Vizepräsidenten der Kultusgemeinde, u. den neuen Anti-
semitismus in Oesterreich.
v. H. von 5–½7h, die Gattin von ½7–½8h – ladet uns für Sonntag ein, ½5h – 4½ Stunde „amüsirt“!! v. H. ein Stundennehmer mit Zuwaage an Unterricht u. an Weib, ein „Mäzen“ mit der leeren Tasche!
Um ¾12h nachts Kurzschluß!
From Deutsch (postcardOC A/279): we will stick with my version of the Schubert song.
To Deutsch (postcard): I shall listen.

Violin from 10:45 to 11:45: he recounts the story of his application to the Ravag, and reads out a letter from Ast and his rejection through Kabasta. Concerning a conversation with Dr. Löwenherz, Vice-President of the Jewish Religious Community, and the new anti-Semitism
in Austria.

Hoboken from 5 o’clock to 6:30, his wife from 6:30 to 7:30 – invites us for Sunday at 4:30 – for four and a half hours, to "amuse"!! Hoboken as a lesson-taker with bonus of extra tuition, and for his wife: a "Maecenas" with empty pockets!
At 11:45 at night, short circuit!

sdo:itemDesc.dc:title: Diary entry by Schenker November 28, 1934
sdo:itemDesc.dc:description: A summary of the contents of the record (currently unused)
sdo:itemDesc.dc:subject: A list of subjects (currently unused)

tei:ab.tei:seg: Nach Tisch fällt die Ruhe aus, weil Mozio zur Jause bei uns ist: ¾4–6h! Verspricht Abtragung der Schuld für 1935 (!?!) bis Wachsberg Possibly the lawyer Dr. Emil Wachsberg, whose offices were at Opernring 8 in the 1st district of Vienna (see Wiener Adreßbuch. Lehmanns Wohnungsanzeiger 1934, 75th year, vol. 1, p. 1441). bezahlt ist; erzählt von seinen Schwierigkeiten, von der unwahren Darstellung der Lage in Oesterreich! Empfiehlt die neue Kurzwellen-Therapie eines Dr. Weissenberg! Bittet die Schuld nicht löschen zu lassen (im beiderseitigen Interesse).
Mit Lie-Liechen Wege, gehe sehr schlecht! Woflf – Salzer am Vormittag, keine Mittagruhe u. dann Mozio!

Das Schubert-Lied im Rundfunk. On September 25, 1934, the Austrian radio corporation (RAVAG), at Deutsch’s suggestion, organized a competition whereby a suitable text for an untexted Schubert song was sought. As the song was also unfinished, it was first completed by Schenker (see Otto Erich Deutsch, Ein Preissauschreiben der RAVAG. Ein Schubert-Lied ohne Worte, Radio Wien, No. 52, September 21, 1934, 10th year, pp. 6, 13, 20). The competition was won by Prisca Maria Mader (see diary entry for November 20). Her winning text was published in Radio Wien under the pseudonym Mary Mahler; it was performed on the radio by Josef Hueber, with an introduction by Deutsch ("Ergebnis des Preisausschreibens: Ein Dichter zu einem unbekannten Schubertlied gesucht," Radio Wien, No. 9, November 23, 1934, 11th year, p. 48).

After lunch, the peace is disturbed because Mozio is with us for afternoon snack: 3:45 to 6 o’clock! He promises to take care of his debt for 1935 (!?!) until Wachsberg has been paid; he speaks of his difficulties, of the untrue portrayal of the state of affairs in Austria! He recommends the new high-frequency radiotherapy of a Dr. Weissenberg! He asks me not to have his debt cancelled (in the interests of both of us).
Errands with Lie-Liechen; I walk very badly! Wolf – Salzer in the morning, no peace at midday, and then Mozio!
The Schubert song on the radio.

sdo:itemDesc.dc:title: Diary entry by Schenker November 29, 1934
sdo:itemDesc.dc:description: A summary of the contents of the record (currently unused)
sdo:itemDesc.dc:subject: A list of subjects (currently unused)

tei:ab.tei:seg: Von Rosl (Br.): hartes, aber richtiges Urteil über Victor! Meldet eigene Sorgen, haben viel auf sich genommen: Klara, Hella, Paul.
Frau Deutsch (tel.): beklagt sich über Frau v. H. – Lie-Liechen beruhigt sie.
Von Jonas (Br.OJ 12/6, [39]): wird klagen; 2 Exemplare der Unterlage.
From Rosl (letter): a severe but correct judgment about Victor! She reports her difficulties, has taken a great many of them upon her own shoulders: Klara, Hella, Paul.
Mrs. Deutsch (by telephone): she complains about Mrs. Hoboken – Lie-Liechen calms her.
From Jonas (letterOJ 12/6, [39]): he will take legal action: two copies of the document.

sdo:itemDesc.dc:title: Diary entry by Schenker November 30, 1934
sdo:itemDesc.dc:description: A summary of the contents of the record (currently unused)
sdo:itemDesc.dc:subject: A list of subjects (currently unused)

tei:ab.tei:seg: Dr. Wurmfeld (um ½11h): findet mich gut.

v. Hoboken: „. . so oft Jonas in Wien ist, pumpt er mich an, für sich u. Wassermann. Possibly the G. Wasserman from whom Jonas received a letter in 1964 (OJ 36/244, [1]). Ich kann Jonas nicht dauernd auf dem Rück tragen.“ Fabriksmarke: Ton u. Eva: Si non e vero, e bon trovato! "Even if it is not true, at least it is well made up!"
Dr. Wurmfeld (at 10:30): he finds me well.
Hoboken: "whenever Jonas is in Vienna he pumps me for money, for himself and Wassermann. I cannot be forever carrying Jonas on my back." Factory stamp: Ton and Eva: Si non e vero, e bonben trovato!
